item.title: Intel Preparing New Linux "PerfMon" Performance Monitoring Support For IOMMU
item.description: With the Intel VT-d 4.0 specification there is performance monitoring "PerfMon" infrastructure introduced. A new patch series from Intel is preparing for IOMMU performance monitoring with the Linux kernel code...

item.title: CentOS Automotive SIG Making Progress On Linux For Cars With AutoSD
item.description: In addition to the CentOS Hyperscale SIG making great progress on adapting CentOS Stream for hyperscaler needs, at the opposite end of the table is the CentOS Automotive SIG with their "AutoSD" platform they continue working on adapting to make CentOS Stream suitable for use within vehicles...

item.title: Mesa 22.3.3 Brings More Intel & Radeon Driver Fixes, KDE Plasma Hang Workaround
item.description: For those sticking to the bi-weekly Mesa 22.3 point releases rather than riding Mesa Git, Mesa 22.3.3 is out today in providing the very latest fixes to this collection of open-source OpenGL and Vulkan drivers...

item.title: AMD RDNA3 ISA Reference Guide Published
item.description: Following last month's launch of the Radeon RX 7900 series graphics cards, AMD's GPUOpen group has now published the instruction set architecture (ISA) programming guide for those interested in RDNA3 GPUs...

item.title: ASRock Industrial Partners With Canonical For Ubuntu-Certified Devices
item.description: ASRock Industrial, the independent company spun out of ASRock that is focused on industrial computers, edge systems, hardware for retail environments, has now partnered with Canonical to begin offering certified devices for Ubuntu Linux...

item.title: Open-Source RADV Driver Adds Radeon Memory Visualizer Support
item.description: A six month old merge request to Mesa was finally merged today for enabling Radeon Memory Visualizer (RMV) support with the Radeon "RADV" Vulkan driver...

item.title: DragonFlyBSD's HAMMER2 File-System Being Ported To NetBSD
item.description: NetBSD continues using the FFS file-system by default while it's offered ZFS support that has been slowly improving -- in NetBSD-CURRENT is the ability to use ZFS as the root file-system if first booting to FFS, for example. There may be another modern file-system option soon with an effort underway to port DragonFlyBSD's HAMMER2 over to NetBSD...

item.title: Open-Source NVIDIA Vulkan Driver "NVK" Begins Running Talos Principle... Slowly
item.description: The NVK open-source Vulkan driver for NVIDIA GPUs that has seen a lot of progress over the past year is now able to run some games like The Talos Principle, which was the launch title for Vulkan 1.0. While the NVK driver is correctly rendering, it's still slow until the kernel driver side is sorted out with re-clocking...

item.title: Chrome 109 Released With New CSS Features, MathML Core, CHIPS
item.description: Google on Tuesday released their first post-holidays update to the cross-platform Chrome web browser...

item.title: Python 3.12 Alpha 4 Released For Testing
item.description: While many haven't even moved yet to the very speedy Python 3.11 that was released back in October, for those wanting to do some bleeding-edge testing the fourth alpha of Python 3.12 is already out...

item.title: Fedora 38 Features Approved For Unified Kernel, mdadm BIOS RAID, Xfce 4.18
item.description: At today's Fedora Engineering and Steering Committee (FESCo) more features were approved for the Fedora 38 release coming up in April...

item.title: Intel Xeon Platinum 8490H "Sapphire Rapids" Performance Benchmarks
item.description: Now that the 4th Gen Xeon Scalable "Sapphire Rapids" and Xeon CPU Max Series overview is out of the way, you are probably very eager to see some independent performance benchmarks of the much anticipated Sapphire Rapids CPUs that are going up against AMD 4th Gen EPYC "Genoa" processors for 2023... For kicking off our Sapphire Rapids benchmarking, first up is a look at the Xeon Platinum 8490H performance under Linux as the flagship SKU.

item.title: Intel Launches 4th Gen Xeon Scalable "Sapphire Rapids", Xeon CPU Max Series
item.description: Intel has announced the 4th Gen Xeon Scalable "Sapphire Rapids" CPUs today along with the Xeon CPU Max Series (Sapphire Rapids HBM) and Data Center GPU Max Series (Ponte Vecchio). Here is an overview of today's announcements prior to getting to some initial Sapphire Rapids Linux benchmarks on Phoronix.

item.description: Last year with the release of Ubuntu 22.04 LTS there was a beta real-time kernel offering from Canonical...

item.title: Linux Preparing To Disable Drivers For Microsoft's RNDIS Protocol
item.description: With the next Linux kernel cycle we could see upstream disable their driver support for Microsoft's Remote Network Driver Interface Specification (RNDIS) protocol due to security concerns...

item.title: More AMD Zen 4 Tuning Ongoing For GCC 13 Compiler
item.description: GCC compiler expert Jan Hubicka at SUSE began working on AMD Zen 4 compiler tuning patches that began landing in December for the GCC 13 compiler that will debut as stable in a few months. It looks like the work isn't over on Znver4 tuning with another patch being sent out today for fine-tuning the latest AMD CPU microarchitecture...

item.title: CentOS Hyperscale SIG Caps Off A Busy 2022
item.description: Established two years ago was the CentOS Hyperscale SIG for a group of engineers from Facebook, Twitter, and other hyperscalers in making optional changes to CentOS Stream to better suit the Linux distribution to their internal needs...

item.title: Microsoft's Dozen Up To A 98.5% Pass Rate For Vulkan 1.0
item.description: Microsoft's Dozen "dzn", which was merged to Mesa last year as Vulkan implemented on Direct3D 12, is onto a 98.5% pass rate for its Vulkan 1.0 coverage...

item.title: AMD Rolling Out New Website Area For Zen Software Studio
item.description: For those making use of AMD's Optimizing C/C++/Fortran compilers, ZenNN library, profiling software, and various other CPU-based software resources for EPYC and Ryzen processors, AMD is in the process of rolling out a new area on the website for highlighting these Zen Software Studio assets...

item.title: AMD Ryzen 5 7600 / Ryzen 7 7700 / Ryzen 9 7900 Linux Performance
item.description: Last week at the AMD CES 2023 keynote hosted by Lisa Su, new 65 Watt Ryzen 7000 series processors were announced. These more affordable Zen 4 processors are going retail this week and today marks the embargo lift. Up on the Linux testing block are the Ryzen 5 7600, Ryzen 7 7700, and Ryzen 9 7900 processors.

item.title: Intel Meteor Lake's VPU Linux Driver Updated, UMD Code Posted
item.description: Back in July Intel engineers published the initial open-source driver code around the new Versatile Processing Unit "VPU" coming with Meteor Lake. This VPU block with 14th Gen Core CPUs is intended for AI inference acceleration for deep learning software...

item.title: XFS Progressing On Defragmenting Free Space - Needed For Online Shrinking
item.description: As part of a New Year's Eve patch deluge, XFS developer Darrick Wong sent out patches working on free space defragmenting support, among other work for further enhancing this mature open-source file-system...

item.title: Blender 3.5 Boasts Working Apple Metal Backend, Vulkan Still In Early Stages
item.description: In addition to Blender's back-ends for NVIDIA CUDA and OptiX, Intel oneAPI, and AMD HIP, Blender 3.5 is set to have a working Apple Metal back-end for that proprietary graphics/compute API with accelerated UI/viewport handling to complement the Metal Cycles support...

item.title: Dynamic Triple Buffering Hopefully Will Land For GNOME 44
item.description: For over two years Canonical has been working on dynamic triple buffering for the GNOME desktop with the Mutter compositor. This triple-buffering-when-needed can dramatically boost the desktop performance especially in cases like Intel integrated graphics and Raspberry Pi boards. The triple buffering work hasn't been upstreamed yet but the hope is that it may finally be ready for upstream inclusion with GNOME 44...

item.title: RISC-V Hibernation Support / Suspend-To-Disk Nears The Linux Kernel
item.description: While the open RISC-V processor architecture has proven to be highly successful, one of the features that it hasn't yet supported with the Linux kernel to this point has been system hibernation / suspend-to-resume, but that support is now on the way...

item.title: Linux 6.2-rc3 Released - "Starting To Look A Lot More Normal"
item.description: Linus Torvalds released Linux 6.2-rc3 a few hours early today and noted that things are "starting to look a lot more normal" in terms of the code churn for this stage of the Linux 6.2 development cycle now that the holiday period has passed...

item.title: AVX2 & AVX-512 Optimized Versions Of ARIA Cipher Coming With Linux 6.3
item.description: The ARIA block cipher devised by South Korean researchers is being sped up by AVX2 and AVX-512 for its Linux kernel implementation...

item.title: AMD Begins Sending In "New Stuff" For Their Graphics Driver With Linux 6.3
item.description: AMD sent out an initial batch of "new stuff" for their AMDGPU/AMDKFD kernel graphics driver code to begin queuing in DRM-Next ahead of the Linux 6.3 cycle kicking off during the back-half of February...

item.title: DragonFlyBSD Adds Temperature Sensor Support For AMD Zen 3 / Zen 4
item.description: While DragonFlyBSD has previously praised the performance of AMD Ryzen Threadripper CPUs going back to the Zen 2 days, it's taken them until this weekend to get temperature sensor monitoring working for Family 19h processors: Zen 3, Zen 3+, and Zen 4 CPUs...

item.title: Mir 2.11 Released With A Fix Around XWayland Use
item.description: A new version of Mir has been released, which in recent years has been serving as a Wayland compositor and used for various niche use-cases like smart exercise mirrors and other IoT and kiosk-type deployments...

item.title: OBS Studio 29 Released With AV1 Encode Additions, Upward Compression Filter
item.description: OBS Studio 29.0 is out this weekend as the latest major feature release to this very popular, cross-platform software for screencasting and screen recording purposes...

item.title: Linux 4.9.337 Released To End Out The 2016 LTS Series
item.description: The Linux 4.9 kernel was released back in 2016 and Greg Kroah-Hartman today issued the final point release for that kernel series with the Long Term Support (LTS) period now expired...
